This move comes as Nvidia awaits approval for its $40 billion acquisition of Arm Holdings PLC, showcasing its strategy to leverage licensed technology for future AI business. The new CPU, announced at Nvidia's annual GTC developers conference, aims to challenge the dominance of Intel and AMD in the server CPU space.

title: Nvidia steps up competition with Intel and AMD with first data-center CPU, based on Arm
summary: Nvidia introduced its first data-center CPU, named Grace, based on Arm technology, aiming to intensify its competition with Intel and AMD in the artificial-intelligence market. This move signals Nvidia's commitment to the chip-making sector, leveraging technology from its acquisition target, Arm Holdings PLC, to tap into the growing AI business. The announcement was made during Nvidia’s annual GTC developers conference by CEO Jensen Huang.

title: Nvidia debuts Grace, its first data center CPU for advanced AI workloads
summary: Nvidia has launched Grace, its first Arm-based data center CPU, specifically designed to handle the demanding requirements of advanced AI workloads like natural language processing and drug discovery. Grace is intended to work in conjunction with Nvidia's GPUs to deliver significantly higher performance than current systems, and will power future supercomputers like the Alps project at the Swiss National Computing Center. The company also announced other AI initiatives, including the cloud-native DGX SuperPOD and the Jarvis conversational AI framework.

title: Nvidia announces Omniverse Enterprise suite for real-time, photorealistic graphics design
summary: Nvidia introduced Omniverse Enterprise, a new suite designed for real-time collaborative 3D design and graphics rendering. This platform enables geographically dispersed teams to work together on complex projects, leveraging photorealistic rendering and real-time ray tracing. Key components include Omniverse Nucleus, Connectors for third-party apps, and Nvidia's own Create and View applications, with companies like BMW Group and Ericsson already using it for digital twin creation and 5G network simulation.

title: The Alienware m15 Ryzen Edition R5 is an AMD-NVIDIA combo over a decade in the making
summary: The Alienware m15 Ryzen Edition R5 is announced, marking the first Alienware notebook in over a decade to combine AMD processors with NVIDIA graphics. This gaming laptop features Ryzen 5000 series CPUs and NVIDIA RTX 30-series GPUs, along with other advancements like 3200Mhz DDR4 memory and a CHERRY-based mechanical keyboard. It will be available starting April 7th in China, April 20th in the US, and May 4th globally, with select configurations beginning at $1793.98.

title: Intel Launches Its Most Advanced Performance Data Center Platform
summary: Intel has launched its 3rd Gen Intel Xeon Scalable processors (code-named “Ice Lake”), marking its most advanced performance data center platform. These processors offer an average 46% increase in performance for popular data center workloads, alongside built-in AI acceleration and advanced security features. The platform is optimized for a broad range of applications across cloud, network, and intelligent edge environments, with significant industry adoption already underway.

title: What HR tools are NVIDIA using to hire 600 Israelis?
summary: NVIDIA is set to hire 600 new employees in Israel, increasing its headcount by 25%. Gideon Rosenberg, NVIDIA's HR leader, discusses the tools and strategies they use for recruitment, including Textio for inclusive job descriptions and LinkedIn Recruiter licenses. The company also shares its experience adapting to the pandemic, its plans for onboarding new hires, and its intention to adopt a hybrid work model post-Covid-19.

title: Volvo partners with Aurora for hub-to-hub autonomous trucking
summary: Volvo Group has selected Aurora as its primary technology partner for developing autonomous, hub-to-hub trucking solutions in North America, making it the last major truck manufacturer to choose such a partner. This partnership builds on previous quiet collaborations since 2018 and aims to integrate Aurora's Driver software with Volvo's technology for a "trucking-as-a-service" model. Aurora continues to expand its portfolio, having recently acquired Uber's Advanced Technologies Group and partnering with PACCAR.

title: Arm’s v9 Architecture Explains Why Nvidia Needs To Buy It
summary: This article explores why Nvidia's $40 billion acquisition of Arm Holdings, initially questioned, makes strategic sense following Arm's v9 architecture announcement. The v9 architecture's focus on integrating vector math, matrix math, and digital signal processing into CPUs, alongside new security features and a "Realms" memory partitioning system, suggests a future where specialized, highly integrated compute on-device is paramount. Nvidia's move to acquire Arm is positioned as a bet on this evolving compute landscape, where a single, malleable architecture can support a vast array of devices from IoT to datacenters, potentially limiting the expansion of hybrid CPU-GPU models for certain workloads.

title: Integrating with Telephone Networks to Enable Real-Time AI Services
summary: Ribbon Communications, in collaboration with NVIDIA, developed a solution to analyze contact center calls in real-time using advanced AI. The Ribbon AI gateway acts as a secure bridge converting Real-time Transport Protocol (RTP) audio streams into an AI-acceptable audio format for transcription and analysis. This architecture allows businesses to dynamically control call handling using REST APIs for applications like regulatory compliance, fraud analysis, and sentiment analysis, addressing critical limitations of delayed call recording analysis.

title: Palo Alto Networks (PANW) Stock Live Price, Chart & News
summary: This article provides live stock price, chart, and news for Palo Alto Networks (PANW). It includes current and historical performance data, fundamental metrics, company information, and recent news headlines related to the company. The page also offers quick links to various stock-related information such as price prediction, brokers, dividends, and earnings.

title: Why is Nvidia a better investment than Intel in a virus-hit market?
summary: This article compares Nvidia (NASDAQ: NVDA) and Intel (NASDAQ: INTC) as investments in a market heavily impacted by supply chain issues and increased demand for digital services. It highlights Nvidia's stronger profitability and revenue growth in the past year, driven by its GPU portfolio and expansion into data centers, making it a stronger buy recommendation despite higher relative valuation. In contrast, Intel, while still a dominant player, faces weaker guidance and an uncertain short-term outlook, with its stock viewed as a riskier investment at present.

title: Nintendo to Use Faster Nvidia Chips in New 2021 Switch Model
summary: Nintendo Co. plans to incorporate an upgraded Nvidia Corp. chip with enhanced graphics and processing into a new Switch model for the year-end shopping season. This new iteration will support Nvidia’s Deep Learning Super Sampling (DLSS) technology, allowing for 4K quality visuals when docked to a TV, in addition to an OLED display upgrade. The improvements aim to deliver higher-fidelity graphics more efficiently through AI.

title: Fidelity Magellan ETF ETF Price, Holdings, & News (BATS:FMAG)
summary: The Fidelity Magellan ETF (FMAG) is an actively managed, non-transparent ETF that invests in fundamentally selected firms globally, tracking the S&P 500 TR USD index. Launched in February 2021, the fund has assets under management of $266.85 million and a net expense ratio of 0.59%. Its top holdings include major tech companies like NVIDIA, Microsoft, and Amazon.com.

title: Qualcomm Completes Acquisition of NUVIA
summary: Qualcomm Incorporated announced the completion of its acquisition of NUVIA for $1.4 billion. This acquisition aims to enhance Qualcomm's CPU roadmap, integrating next-generation CPUs across various products including smartphones, laptops, and automotive systems. The first Qualcomm Snapdragon platforms featuring these new internally designed CPUs are expected to sample in the second half of 2022.

title: A $69 Million NFT
summary: This article discusses the booming NFT market, highlighted by Beeple's $69 million sale at Christie's, alongside other notable NFT sales and crypto-adjacent investing trends by institutions like JPMorgan and Simplify U.S. Equity PLUS Bitcoin ETF. It also covers significant regulatory developments in the U.S. concerning DAOs and token classification, an upcoming Ethereum upgrade (EIP 1559), and critical tax implications for NFT investors, emphasizing short-term vs. long-term capital gains and the "collectibles" classification.

title: Changing Of The Guard For HPC And Big Iron At HPE
summary: Pete Ungaro, the long-time head of Cray and then HPE's High Performance Computing & Mission Critical Solutions group, is stepping down, with Justin Hotard taking over. This leadership change occurs as HPE continues to navigate a challenging market, focusing on profitability and leveraging the Cray acquisition to scale its HPC business. The company is making strategic bets on services and utility-style pricing for on-premises systems, with recent financial results indicating these efforts are beginning to pay off despite overall revenue and profit declines in some segments.

title: Gemini-1 Spreads Millions of Processors Into RAM
summary: GSI Technology introduces Gemini-1, a processor-in-memory chip that accelerates specific mathematical functions by up to 100x compared to traditional processors. Designed as an "associative processing unit" (APU), Gemini-1 integrates about 2 million simple processing elements directly within SRAM cells, making it highly specialized for parallel search and cryptography algorithms. While not a general-purpose CPU, it excels at tasks like Hamming distance and Tanimoto similarity calculations by eliminating the data transfer bottleneck between CPU and RAM.

title: Introducing the 2021 Adobe Analytics Champions
summary: Adobe announced its 2021 Adobe Analytics Champions program, recognizing 40 individuals for their expertise and dedication to Adobe Analytics. These Champions will participate in career development, knowledge sharing, and provide feedback to Adobe product teams, while also helping other users improve their skills. The program celebrates passionate and knowledgeable Adobe Analytics users globally.

title: Google, Microsoft, Qualcomm Protest Nvidia’s Acquisition of Arm Ltd.
summary: Google, Microsoft, and Qualcomm are among several major technology companies that are complaining to U.S. antitrust regulators about Nvidia Corp.'s proposed $40 billion acquisition of Arm Ltd. These companies fear the deal will harm competition in a critical sector of the industry. Some even urge regulators to block the acquisition.

title: 'SOXL': The Fight for Semiconductors Is Getting Chippy
summary: The article discusses how a global semiconductor shortage could provide tailwinds for semiconductor ETFs like the Direxion Daily Semiconductor Bull 3X ETF (SOXL). President Joe Biden's pledge to address the shortage and develop a long-term strategy, along with increased demand for consumer electronics due to the pandemic, are cited as contributing factors to the sector's bullish momentum. The shortage impacts various industries beyond traditional technology, including automotive, highlighting the broad significance of semiconductor supply.

title: Google, Microsoft, Qualcomm Protest Nvidia’s Acquisition of Arm Ltd.
summary: Google, Microsoft, and Qualcomm are among several major technology companies that have registered complaints with U.S. antitrust regulators regarding Nvidia's proposed $40 billion acquisition of Arm Ltd. The companies fear the deal will harm competition and limit equal access to vital technology, with some pushing for the acquisition to be blocked. Nvidia's shares experienced a decline following this news.

title: Nestle, Nvidia, and the Changing Global Equity Markets
summary: The article analyzes the shifting dynamics of global equity markets over the past decade, characterized by the dominance of U.S. technology stocks like Nvidia, in contrast to traditional companies like Nestle. It highlights the increased concentration of U.S. market indexes in technology and consumer cyclical sectors, and discusses current valuation opportunities in non-U.S. markets and value sectors like energy.

title: Samsung wins Intel foundry order; TSMC takes GPU deal
summary: Samsung Electronics has secured its first foundry order from Intel to produce southbridge chipsets at its Austin, Texas plant, while TSMC will handle Intel's GPU production. This order is seen as a strategic win for Samsung, establishing a foundation for future core chip orders, even though it missed out on the GPU deal. The move highlights Intel's strategy to outsource production to focus on flagship CPUs and intensifies competition in the foundry market where Samsung is a distant second to TSMC.
source: The Korea Economic Daily Global Edition
source_domain: The Korea Economic Daily Global Edition

title: Supermicro Unveils NVIDIA GPU Server Test Drive Program with Leading Channel Partners to Deliver Workload Qualification on Remote Supermicro Servers
summary: Supermicro has launched a new GPU test-drive program called STEP, in collaboration with NVIDIA and leading channel partners. This program allows customers to remotely test Supermicro's 2U HGX A100 4-GPU or 4U HGX A100 8-GPU systems, enabling them to qualify their advanced workloads on high-performance platforms. The initiative aims to accelerate time-to-market solutions for AI and HPC applications by providing access to cutting-edge NVIDIA HGX A100 technology.

title: Check out Oddity Tech Ltd's stock price (ODD) in real time
summary: This article provides real-time stock information for Oddity Tech Ltd (ODD) on NASDAQ, including its current price, volume, and 52-week range. It also lists recent news and analyst commentary related to the company, highlighting its financial performance and strategic moves in the beauty and wellness sector. Key financial stats, profitability ratios, and upcoming events like earnings dates are also presented.

title: Intel CEO Bob Swan to Be Replaced by VMware Chief
summary: Intel Corp. Chief Executive Officer Bob Swan will be replaced by VMware Inc. CEO Pat Gelsinger, who is returning to Intel more than a decade after leaving. This leadership change comes as Intel faces manufacturing delays, increased competition, and customers designing their own chips. Gelsinger's appointment is seen as a move to bring back technical and home-grown leadership to address the company's challenges.

title: Qualcomm eyes challenge to Apple, Intel with $1.4 billion deal for chip startup
summary: Qualcomm Inc announced its acquisition of Nuvia Inc, a chip startup founded by former Apple executives, for $1.4 billion. This move aims to enhance Qualcomm's chip performance in smartphones, laptops, and automotive processors, challenging rivals like Apple and Intel. The deal also helps Qualcomm reduce its reliance on Arm Ltd's licensed technology by incorporating Nuvia's custom core designs.

title: Rock star chip designer Jim Keller joins Tenstorrent
summary: Legendary computer chip designer Jim Keller has joined Toronto startup Tenstorrent Inc. as its new president and chief technology officer. Keller, known for his work at AMD, Apple, and Tesla, will guide Tenstorrent in its mission to create a machine learning training chip that utilizes software to optimize computing power and increase efficiency, challenging established players like Intel, AMD, and Nvidia.

title: Why You Should Consider Investing in Samsung -- And How
summary: This article explores why Samsung Electronics Co., Ltd. (SSNLF) is a compelling investment opportunity, highlighting its dominance in smartphones, advancements in 5G and 6G technology, and strategic shift towards logic chips. It details Samsung's business segments and provides guidance on how U.S. investors can buy its shares, including direct purchase on the Korean exchange or through specific ETFs like iShares MSCI South Korea Capped ETF (EWY).

title: Speaker Spotlight: "staying on top of trends involves being a gamer yourself" says Roundhill Investments' Mario Stefanidis
summary: Mario Stefanidis of Roundhill Investments discusses the intersection of finance and the games industry, emphasizing the importance of being an active gamer to understand evolving trends. He highlights how the COVID-19 pandemic accelerated growth in gaming and predicts future trends like cloud gaming expansion and new VR titles. Stefanidis also shares insights into Roundhill Investments' focus on thematic investing in digital media and entertainment.

title: Isaac Gym is NVIDIA’s reinforcement learning accelerator for robotics
summary: NVIDIA announced the preview release of Isaac Gym, a new physics simulation environment designed to accelerate reinforcement learning for AI and robotics research. This GPU-accelerated platform allows researchers to train complex RL tasks, previously requiring thousands of CPU cores, on a single GPU significantly faster and more efficiently. Isaac Gym leverages NVIDIA's PhysX engine and offers an end-to-end GPU RL pipeline, making advanced robotics research more accessible.

title: Element AI sold for $230-million as founders saw value mostly wiped out, document reveals
summary: Montreal startup Element AI Inc. was sold to ServiceNow Inc. for US$230-million, a deal that saw the value of common shares held by founders and many employees largely wiped out due to the company's financial struggles and inability to meet product development goals. While institutional shareholders are expected to recoup investments, the sale highlights the challenges faced by the highly hyped AI firm despite significant venture capital and government funding. The transaction involves ServiceNow retaining Element AI's research scientists and patents, effectively abandoning its business.

title: Samsung clinches 2nd deal to make Nvidia’s latest gaming chips
summary: Samsung Electronics has secured a second deal this year to manufacture Nvidia's next-generation gaming GPUs, the Ampere GeForce RTX30 series, using its 8-nanometer process technology. This contract is significant as Samsung aims to narrow the gap with industry leader TSMC in the global foundry market, investing heavily in technology like EUV lithography and expanding its production capabilities. The deal for Nvidia's popular RTX3080 chip highlights Samsung's growing presence amid high demand and fierce competition.
source: The Korea Economic Daily Global Edition
source_domain: The Korea Economic Daily Global Edition

title: Intel, Nvidia probed over tech allegedly used against Uighurs
summary: Two US legislators, Senator Marco Rubio and Representative Jim McGovern, have sent letters to Intel Corp and Nvidia Corp, probing the sale of advanced computer chips allegedly used by China for mass surveillance on Uighurs in the Xinjiang region. The letters sought information on the companies' exports to China and whether they ensured their technology was not used for human rights abuses. Both companies have responded, with Intel stating it does not tolerate human rights violations and Nvidia declining to comment.

title: Uber sells ATG self-driving business to Aurora at $4 billion
summary: Uber Technologies Inc is selling its autonomous driving unit, Uber Advanced Technologies Group (ATG), to self-driving car startup Aurora in an equity deal valued at $4 billion. Uber will also invest $400 million in Aurora, giving it approximately 26% ownership, with the aim to accelerate Uber's path to profitability by the end of 2021. This sale marks a significant drop in ATG's valuation from its previous $7.25 billion.

title: NAND competition heats up as SK Hynix unveils 176-layer flash memory
summary: SK Hynix has developed 176-layer NAND flash memory, making it the industry's highest-density chip, following Micron Technology. This new chip improves cell read latency by 20% and data transfer speeds by 33%, enhancing cost competitiveness and productivity. The move intensifies competition in the NAND market, with Samsung also planning significant investments, as demand for NAND memory chips rises due to global shifts towards working from home.
source: The Korea Economic Daily Global Edition
source_domain: The Korea Economic Daily Global Edition

title: Arm CEO expects regulators to ‘take a good look’ at the Nvidia deal
summary: Arm CEO Simon Segars anticipates regulatory bodies will thoroughly review Nvidia's proposed $40 billion acquisition of the British chip designer. The deal, announced in September, faces hurdles including obtaining approvals from various global jurisdictions and concerns from Chinese regulators and some British entrepreneurs. Segars emphasized that Arm's ability to provide technology globally would not change with the ownership, but acknowledged the complex regulatory process.

title: Why Teradyne’s offerings provide value to end-user markets
summary: This article examines Teradyne's (TER) diverse product line and how it delivers value to its customer base across various end-user markets. It details Teradyne's semiconductor test platforms like FLEX, J750, and Magnum, and how they cater to industries such as mobile, automotive, and data storage. The article also highlights Teradyne's key customers and its presence in semiconductor-focused ETFs.

title: NVIDIA Unlikely to Compete with AMD on 7-nm Node
summary: Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) is developing ray tracing technology for its future GPUs, with plans to launch 7-nm gaming GPUs ahead of NVIDIA. NVIDIA, however, is not rushing to adopt 7-nm technology, focusing instead on affordable and power-efficient 12-nm FinFET processes for its current Turing GPUs. The article suggests NVIDIA might skip 7-nm and directly move to 7-nm+ or 5-nm nodes in the future.

title: NVIDIA Broadens Product Portfolio to Tap New Computing Markets
summary: NVIDIA has seen exponential growth in recent years, driven by its strategy of leveraging a single GPU architecture across diverse applications and increasing its average selling price. The company is now expanding its product portfolio into new markets, such as AI, by investing more in software and exploring new verticals. Despite short-term challenges, NVIDIA's long-term growth prospects are strong as it broadens its addressable market.

title: Why Some Exposure to VanEck’s Gaming ETF Is Prudent
summary: The article discusses the growth and mainstream adoption of the esports industry, highlighting its global phenomenon status and substantial investment from various sectors beyond just tech. It suggests that the VanEck Vectors Video Gaming and eSports ETF (ESPO) is a prudent investment for those seeking exposure to the gaming and related industries, including major players like Tencent and Activision Blizzard, as well as chipmakers like NVIDIA and AMD. The ETF is presented as a way to capitalize on the continued surge in the gaming and esports market.

title: Nvidia, Epic to bring 'Fortnite' back to iPhones in 'near future'
summary: Nvidia and Epic Games are collaborating to bring "Fortnite" back to Apple iPhones through Nvidia's GeForce NOW streaming game service in the near future. The game was removed from Apple's App Store in August due to Epic's billing system, which violated Apple's rules. This return route bypasses Apple's App Store rules by utilizing the iPhone's Safari web browser.

title: Earnings: Nvidia Corp. (NASDAQ: NVDA) reports Q3 2021 financial results
summary: Nvidia reported a sharp increase in third-quarter earnings for 2021, surpassing market projections. Adjusted profit climbed to $2.91 per share, and revenue rose 57% annually to $4.73 billion, both exceeding Street views. Despite strong results, the company's stock dropped during after-hours trading following the announcement.

title: Chip maker NVIDIA signs in-car entertainment system deal with Hyundai Motor
summary: NVIDIA Corp announced a deal with Hyundai Motor Group to integrate its NVIDIA DRIVE in-vehicle information and entertainment system into all Hyundai, Kia, and Genesis models starting in 2022. This system, which includes hardware and perpetually updatable AI software, is already in use in some Genesis models. NVIDIA declined to provide specific vehicle numbers but noted that Hyundai Motor Group shipped over 7 million vehicles in 2019, indicating a large-scale implementation.

title: Apple's new Macs could revive the PC chip wars, benefit Qualcomm: Analysts
summary: Apple is expected to unveil new Mac computers using its own in-house Arm-based processor chips, a move that could disrupt the PC chip market currently dominated by Intel and AMD. This shift could benefit companies like Qualcomm, which has been developing Arm-based processors for Windows PCs. Analysts suggest that Apple's entry into this market could accelerate the adoption of Arm-based PCs, despite challenges related to software compatibility.

title: Apple's new Macs could revive the PC chip wars, analysts say
summary: Apple's expected unveiling of new Mac computers with in-house processor chips based on Arm Ltd. technology could re-ignite competition in the PC chip market, currently dominated by Intel and Advanced Micro Devices. This shift marks a departure from Apple's nearly 15-year relationship with Intel and could benefit companies like Qualcomm, which has been adapting Arm-based processors for Windows PCs. Analysts believe Apple's entry will accelerate the adoption of Arm-based PCs, although challenges remain for software compatibility.

title: Waldman to leave Mellanox two decades after founding unicorn
summary: Eyal Waldman, president and CEO of Mellanox Technologies Ltd., announced his departure from the company he founded in 1999. His exit follows last year's $6.9 billion sale of Mellanox to Nvidia Corp., a deal that rewarded Waldman approximately $250 million for his 3.6% stake. Waldman led Mellanox to a Nasdaq IPO in 2007 and is recognized as a prominent Israeli tech entrepreneur.

title: AMD Agrees to Buy Xilinx for $35 Billion in Stock (Published 2020)
summary: Advanced Micro Devices has agreed to acquire Xilinx for $35 billion in an all-stock deal, aiming to expand its chip business into new markets like 5G communications and automotive electronics. This acquisition is part of a broader trend of consolidation in the chip industry and would position AMD to compete more fiercely with rivals like Nvidia and Intel. The deal is expected to help AMD grow its presence in data centers and enhance its profitability.

title: Huawei, China firms said to seek curbs on Nvidia’s arm deal
summary: Chinese technology companies, including Huawei, have expressed significant concerns to local regulators regarding Nvidia Corp.'s proposed $40 billion acquisition of Arm Ltd. They fear Nvidia might force Arm to cut off Chinese clients, jeopardizing Arm's neutral status in the chip industry and impacting their access to crucial technology. The deal requires approval from various global regulators, with China's endorsement being particularly challenging due to its reliance on American technology and ongoing trade tensions.
source: macau daily times 澳門每日時報
source_domain: macau daily times 澳門每日時報

title: Nvidia’s A100 GPU sets new performance records in MLPerf benchmarks
summary: Nvidia's A100 GPU has set new performance records in the latest MLPerf benchmarks, dominating tests across six application areas for data center and edge computing systems. The A100 GPU significantly outperformed CPUs in image classification and recommender tests, demonstrating extreme cost efficiency benefits for AI inference. Nvidia's systems are also making an impact in various industries, including medical imaging, automotive, and financial services, and are integrated into powerful supercomputers.

title: Opinion: How did Intel lose its Silicon Valley crown?
summary: This article discusses Intel's decline as the leading chip manufacturer in Silicon Valley, examining whether the challenges stem from technological limits or leadership decisions. The chip giant announced a delay in its 7-nanometer manufacturing process and considered outsourcing some production for a key next-generation chip, shocking investors and analysts. This move is seen as a significant setback for the company once considered the standard-bearer of Moore's Law.

title: US firm Nvidia to employ 100 West Bank engineers as salaried workers
summary: Nvidia Corp., which acquired Israel’s Mellanox Technologies Ltd., will employ 100 Palestinian engineers in the West Bank as salaried workers, converting them from subcontractors. This move is hailed as a historic achievement for Palestinian workers, offering them new professional and personal opportunities within the US firm. Mellanox co-founder Eyal Waldman emphasized the positive impact of joint Israeli-Palestinian professional work and urged other companies to follow suit.

title: Semiconductor Market to reach USD 90.80 billion by 2024, Broadcom Inc. and Infineon Technologies AG emerge as Key Contributors to growth | Technavio
summary: The semiconductor market is projected to grow by USD 90.80 billion during 2020-2024, progressing at a CAGR of over 4%. This growth is significantly driven by the rising adoption of semiconductor ICs in automobiles and emerging semiconductor packaging technologies. Broadcom Inc. and Infineon Technologies AG, along with other major players, are identified as key contributors to this market expansion, with the APAC region expected to contribute 76% of the market growth.

title: US tech giant Nvidia unveils ‘breakthrough’ processor sired by Israel team
summary: Nvidia Corp. unveiled a new "breakthrough" processor called the Data Processing Unit (DPU) developed by its Israeli team, Mellanox Technologies Ltd., which Nvidia acquired in 2019 for $7 billion. This DPU is designed to offload data center infrastructure services from the main CPU, significantly freeing up server resources and enhancing performance. Nvidia plans to integrate these DPUs into new server systems by 2021 and projects future versions to be significantly more powerful.

title: Intel Spins Out Omni-Path Interconnect Business Into Stand-Alone Company
summary: Intel has spun out its Omni-Path Architecture high-speed interconnect technology into a new stand-alone company called Cornelis Networks, which has raised $20 million in Series A funding. This move provides an alternative to Nvidia's Mellanox InfiniBand and allows former Intel architects to continue developing and supporting the Omni-Path product line, which Intel had previously de-emphasized. Cornelis Networks aims to support existing customers, sell current products, and develop next-generation interconnect solutions for high-performance computing and AI workloads.

title: Skytrac To Make Iridium Certus Terminals
summary: Skytrac Systems is developing new Iridium satcom products, specifically Iridium Certus terminals, designed to support bandwidth-intensive services such as video streaming. The company's SDL-350 Iridium Certus terminal is highlighted as a key product in this new line. This move aims to enhance capabilities for aviation communications.

title: There's No Such Thing as 'Huang's Law,' Despite Nvidia's AI Lead
summary: This article disputes the notion of "Huang's Law," which posits that AI silicon performance doubles every two years, similar to Moore's Law. The author argues that this "law" is a misinterpretation that conflates Moore's Law (transistor density) and Dennard scaling (performance per watt), and that Nvidia's AI advancements are heavily reliant on Moore's Law and other technological improvements, not an independent phenomenon. Furthermore, it is too early to declare such a law, and the rate of AI/ML improvement may not be sustainable.

title: Arm CTO on company's small, but vital Silicon Valley presence
summary: Arm Limited's CTO, Dipesh Patel, discussed the company's significant presence in Silicon Valley, despite its smaller size compared to its Cambridge, England office. Arm, which employs around 350 people in San Jose, is set to be acquired by Nvidia Corp. The article highlights the historical roots of Arm's Silicon Valley operations dating back to the mid-1990s.

title: Moore’s Law Is Dead. Long Live Huang’s Law.
summary: This article discusses the decline of Moore's Law and introduces "Huang's Law," named after Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang. Huang's Law describes the rapid advancement in specialized computing power, particularly for AI applications, driven by GPUs outpacing general-purpose CPUs. The article argues that specialized hardware will be crucial for developing true AI, even as Moore's Law, which predicted the doubling of computing power every 18 months, has reached its limits.

title: A brewing U.S.-China tech cold war rattles the semiconductor industry
summary: The U.S. semiconductor industry is concerned about a brewing tech cold war with China, fearing disruptions to the global supply chain as trade tensions escalate. Companies are developing strategies like hoarding supplies or relocating production, while the U.S. government is pushing for domestic manufacturing incentives through legislation like the CHIPS for America Act and the American Foundries Act. This push aims to strengthen U.S. leadership in advanced technologies and reduce reliance on foreign chip production.

title: Nvidia Confident U.S.-China Tech War Won’t Stop It From Buying Arm
authors: Ye Zhanqi and Anniek Bao Jensen Huang
summary: Nvidia's CEO Jensen Huang expressed confidence in obtaining regulatory approvals for its $40 billion acquisition of Arm Ltd., despite escalating U.S.-China tech tensions. The deal faces skepticism from Chinese experts and opposition from Arm co-founder Hermann Hauser, who warns of potential job losses and compromised business neutrality. Despite these challenges, Nvidia remains optimistic, citing past regulatory successes.

title: Why Nvidia is spending $40 billion on Arm
summary: Nvidia's $40 billion acquisition of Arm, if completed, would be the largest semiconductor deal ever and is primarily aimed at boosting Nvidia's data center business by integrating Arm's CPU technology with Nvidia's GPUs. The deal raises questions about Nvidia's ability to neutrally license Arm's technology to competitors like Apple and Samsung, but Nvidia plans to operate Arm as an independent, customer-neutral subsidiary. Investors reacted positively to the news, and Nvidia sees significant potential in infusing its AI and graphics chips into Arm's vast ecosystem.

title: ARM: UK-based chip designer sold to US firm Nvidia
summary: UK-based computer chip designer ARM Holdings has been sold to US firm Nvidia for $40bn (£31.2bn), four years after its acquisition by Softbank. Nvidia has pledged to maintain ARM's UK presence, increase staff, and retain its brand, aiming to create a premier AI computing company. However, the deal faces scrutiny and opposition from ARM's co-founders and others due to concerns about potential conflicts of interest, US export control regulations, and its impact on the UK technology sector.

title: ARM: Can 'crown jewel' of UK technology be protected?
summary: The UK government is considering options to protect Cambridge-based ARM Holdings after its acquisition by Nvidia, a move that contrasts with their earlier stance during Softbank's purchase in 2016. ARM's co-founder has criticized the deal, fearing Nvidia will disrupt ARM's business model. While Nvidia promises UK investment, blocking the deal poses challenges given current laws and potential impacts on foreign investment.

title: -Nvidia's Arm deal sparks quick backlash in chip industry
summary: Nvidia's proposed $40 billion acquisition of Arm Ltd is encountering strong opposition from chip industry rivals in South Korea and China, raising concerns about Arm's neutrality and potential competition with Nvidia. Analysts suggest the deal could be detrimental to Arm's ecosystem and may drive customers toward alternative technologies like RISC-V. Despite Nvidia's assurances of maintaining Arm's open licensing model, competitors fear increased licensing fees and intensified competition in emerging markets like self-driving cars.

title: -Nvidia to buy chip designer Arm for $40 bln as SoftBank exits
summary: Nvidia announced its acquisition of UK-based chip designer Arm from SoftBank Group for $40 billion, a deal set to significantly impact the global semiconductor sector. The acquisition poses questions regarding Arm's maintained neutrality under U.S. ownership and faces regulatory scrutiny, particularly in China. Nvidia plans to expand Arm's licensing model and integrate its own IP, while SoftBank exits Arm to raise cash.

title: Nvidia jumps on $40 billion chip deal; analysts expect tough scrutiny
summary: Nvidia's shares surged after announcing a $40 billion deal to acquire UK-based chip designer Arm from SoftBank, marking a potential shift in the chip industry landscape. Analysts anticipate significant regulatory challenges for the acquisition, particularly from China, due to its scale and implications for competition. The deal is seen as a major move for Nvidia, positioning it among top chip suppliers, but also raising concerns among rivals and regulators.

title: Nvidia reaches $40B deal to buy SoftBank's Arm Holdings
summary: Nvidia has agreed to acquire Arm Holdings from SoftBank Group and SoftBank Vision Fund for $40 billion in stock and cash. This deal, which includes $21.5 billion in Nvidia stock and $12 billion cash, aims to position Nvidia strongly in the age of AI, leveraging Arm's processor designs to compete in the data center chip market. SoftBank will retain a less than 10% stake in Arm after the acquisition.

title: Duration: 3 minutes, 1 second.
summary: UK tech giant Arm Holdings is being sold to US company Nvidia for $40bn (£31bn) in a deal that faces regulatory approval and opposition from rivals and politicians. Arm co-founder Hermann Hauser heavily criticized the takeover, calling it an "absolute disaster" that would lead to job losses and destroy the company's business model. Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang has pledged to keep Arm headquartered in Cambridge and invest in a new AI research facility there, but the deal raises concerns about Arm's neutrality and its position in the US-China tech rivalry.

title: Highflying Nvidia’s Deal for Arm Signals Loftier Chip Ambition
summary: Nvidia's $40 billion acquisition of Arm Holdings from SoftBank is poised to significantly impact the global semiconductor industry, further solidifying Nvidia's position. The deal involves a mix of stock and cash, with potential additional payments based on Arm's financial performance. This transaction also marks another major divestment for SoftBank.

title: NVIDIA to Acquire Arm for $40 Billion, Creating World’s Premier Computing Company for the Age of AI
summary: NVIDIA announced it will acquire Arm Limited from SoftBank Group Corp. and the SoftBank Vision Fund for $40 billion. The acquisition aims to create the world's premier computing company for the age of AI, combining NVIDIA’s AI leadership with Arm’s vast computing ecosystem. NVIDIA plans to expand Arm’s R&D presence in Cambridge, UK, establish a world-class AI research and education center, and build an Arm/NVIDIA-powered AI supercomputer, all while maintaining Arm’s open-licensing model and customer neutrality.

title: ERISA lawsuit filed against Nvidia; suit against Cornell settled
summary: An ERISA lawsuit has been filed against Nvidia over its 401(k) plan, with plaintiffs alleging excessive investment management fees and a failure to opt for lower-cost share classes. This complaint, filed by Capozzi Adler, mirrors a recent suit against B. Braun Medical. Concurrently, a long-running class-action lawsuit against Cornell University concerning its 403(b) plan has been settled, with terms yet to be disclosed, after allegations of imprudent retention of target-date funds.

title: The new 2021 Mercedes S-Class goes tech-tastic
summary: The 2021 Mercedes S-Class is revealed as a technological marvel, featuring advanced infotainment, driver assistance systems, and luxurious interior amenities. Despite a familiar exterior, the car is lighter, more aerodynamic, and includes features like Level 3 autonomy, fingerprint recognition, and extensive customization options. Mercedes also emphasizes the car's environmental consciousness with its production plant and use of recycled materials.

title: NVIDIA sued over 401(k) plan fees
summary: NVIDIA has been sued over fees associated with its 401(k) plan. This news is reported by Pensions & Investments, specializing in lawsuits and legal matters concerning retirement plans.

title: Samsung Electronics lands order to produce next-generation chips for U.S. Nvidia
summary: Samsung Electronics has secured a significant foundry order to produce next-generation graphics processing units (GPUs) for Nvidia, specifically the GeForce RTX 30 Series. This marks a strategic win for Samsung, as Nvidia previously relied on TSMC for its GPU production. The deal leverages Samsung's 8-nano fabrication process, aiming to double GPU performance and challenging TSMC's dominance in the foundry market.

title: ‘Fortnite’ Is RTX On! Real-Time Ray Tracing Comes to One of Most Popular Games on the Planet
summary: NVIDIA and Epic Games announced that Fortnite is integrating real-time ray tracing, AI-powered NVIDIA DLSS, and NVIDIA Reflex technology, significantly enhancing the game's visuals and responsiveness. These advancements will be available across all Fortnite modes, including a new "RTX Treasure Run" creative map designed to showcase the ray tracing effects. The collaboration highlights how NVIDIA's GeForce RTX 30 Series GPUs are improving competitive gaming with next-level graphics and performance.

title: Micron Announces GDDR6X Memory, Powering the World's Fastest Graphics Cards
summary: Micron Technology announced GDDR6X, the world's fastest discrete graphics memory solution, capable of reaching system bandwidths up to 1 terabyte per second. This new memory, developed in collaboration with NVIDIA, powers the new NVIDIA GeForce RTX 3090 and GeForce RTX 3080 GPUs, enabling advanced gaming experiences with high resolutions and real-time ray tracing. GDDR6X achieves its speed through innovative four-level pulse amplitude modulation (PAM4) signaling, significantly increasing memory bandwidth and offering lower power consumption per transaction.

title: City's technology chief Louis Stewart hired away by Nvidia Corp.
summary: Louis Stewart, Sacramento's chief innovation officer, is leaving his municipal role to join Nvidia Corp., a Santa Clara-based technology company. He is expected to start his new position in mid-September.

title: Intel plans big stock buyback after shares plummet, boosting prices in after-hours trading
summary: Intel announced a plan to buy back $10 billion of its stock by the end of the year, following a nearly 19% drop in its shares over the past month. This decision resulted in a nearly 4% gain in after-hours trading. The company views these repurchases as prudent given that its shares are trading below intrinsic valuation, amidst struggles with new chip engineering and increased competition from rivals like AMD and Nvidia.

title: Gold Diggers; Nvidia ARMed; TSLA’s Chinese Bevy; Sorry Chevy
summary: This article discusses the current market trends in gold, Nvidia, Tesla, and General Motors. It highlights gold's rallying price despite being considered a "boring" investment, Nvidia's potential acquisition of ARM Holdings, Tesla's fluctuating registration numbers in China despite a rising stock price, and General Motors' reluctance to fully embrace the EV market. The article also provides a rundown of upcoming earnings reports in the retail and semiconductor sectors.

title: Nvidia hurdles $300 billion market cap, which Intel hasn’t topped since the dot-com bust
summary: Nvidia Corp. has surpassed a $300 billion market capitalization for the first time, establishing itself as the largest U.S. chip company. This milestone comes as Nvidia's stock has risen over 100% this year, while Intel's has declined by nearly 20%. Nvidia is set to report its second-quarter earnings soon after achieving this record valuation.

title: Nvidia hurdles $300 billion market cap, which Intel hasn’t topped since the dot-com bust
summary: Nvidia Corp. has achieved a market capitalization exceeding $300 billion for the first time, establishing itself as the largest U.S. chip company. This milestone comes as Nvidia's stock has surged over 100% this year, contrasting sharply with Intel's recent struggles. Nvidia is poised to report its second-quarter earnings soon, with strong market performance leading into the announcement.

title: Swing Trading Semiconductors The IBD Way
summary: This article details Investor's Business Daily's (IBD) swing trading strategy for semiconductor stocks, emphasizing a shift from a semiconductor ETF to individual sector leaders like AMD and Nvidia. It highlights how the strategy adapted to the coronavirus market rally, initially gaining broad exposure through an ETF and later refining positions to focus on outperforming individual stocks. The piece explains IBD's method of identifying and investing in strong leaders for optimal swing trading results.

title: Arista, Juniper, Nvidia Switch Vendor ‘Leaders,’ Says Forrester
summary: A Forrester Research report on programmable switch vendors names Arista Networks, Huawei, Juniper Networks, and Nvidia as "leaders." Arista particularly stood out due to its flexible EOS operating system, while Cisco, despite its significant market presence, was placed in the "strong performers" and "contenders" categories for its IOS-XE and NX-OS platforms, respectively. Nvidia also had a dual presence, with its Cumulus Networks operations named a leader and its Mellanox acquisition a contender.

title: Banking on AI: RBC Builds a DGX-Powered Private Cloud
summary: Royal Bank of Canada (RBC) has built an NVIDIA DGX-powered private cloud to enhance its AI capabilities and transform client experiences, leveraging a strategic investment in AI through its research institute, Borealis AI. This new infrastructure allows RBC to run thousands of simulations and analyze millions of data points rapidly, enabling the development of smart applications and significant savings in total cost of ownership. The initiative showcases RBC's commitment to innovation and its early adoption of emerging technologies to maintain its competitive edge in the financial services industry.

title: Intel's 7nm is Broken, Company Announces Delay Until 2022, 2023
summary: Intel announced a significant delay in the rollout of its 7nm CPUs, pushing their debut to late 2022 or early 2023. This delay is attributed to a "defect mode" causing yield degradation, putting Intel approximately twelve months behind its internal targets for 7nm process. The company is now exploring contingency plans, including the use of third-party foundries for some components and entire chip designs, and plans to increase shipments of 10nm chips by 20%.

title: University of Florida and Nvidia partner to build academia’s fastest supercomputer yet
summary: The University of Florida and Nvidia Corp. are partnering to build what they claim will be the fastest artificial intelligence supercomputer in academia. This machine, an upgrade to UF's existing HiPerGator, will tackle issues like COVID-19 research, rising seas, and personalized medicine, and is made possible by a $25 million donation from Nvidia founder Chris Malachowsky and an additional $25 million in hardware and services from Nvidia. UF also plans to invest $20 million and aims to become a leading AI university, producing 30,000 "AI-enabled graduates" by 2030.

title: Gartner’s 2020 Magic Quadrant for Data Center and Cloud Networking: Key Takeaways
summary: Gartner's 2020 Magic Quadrant for Data Center and Cloud Networking identifies 11 vendors, categorizing them into Leaders, Challengers, Visionaries, and Niche Players based on their vision and execution. Cisco, Arista Networks, and Juniper Networks were named Leaders, recognized for their investments in analytics, product portfolios, and automation capabilities. The report also highlights the strengths and market positions of Challengers like Huawei, Visionaries including VMware and Dell EMC, and Niche Players such as NVIDIA-Mellanox Technologies.

title: Nvidia market value closes in on Intel
summary: Nvidia is nearing Intel in market capitalization for the first time, fueled by a 70% stock surge this year due to the accelerated shift to cloud-based digital services. Nvidia's market cap has reached approximately $245 billion, just shy of Intel's $249 billion. This milestone would position Nvidia as the third-largest chipmaker globally by market cap, trailing only Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. and Samsung Electronics Co.

title: The 10 Biggest Networking Company Acquisitions Of 2020 (So Far)
summary: This article details the 10 biggest networking company acquisitions of 2020 to date, highlighting significant deals made by tech giants like Nvidia, Cisco, and F5 Networks. It covers purchases ranging from billion-dollar agreements to more strategic acquisitions aimed at expanding portfolios in areas like 5G, cloud security, and software-defined networking, despite the economic downturn caused by the global pandemic. The acquisitions underscore the dynamic nature of the networking market and companies' efforts to enhance their services and product offerings.

title: Nvidia surpasses Intel as largest U.S. chip maker by market cap
summary: Nvidia Corp. has surpassed Intel Corp. as the largest U.S. chip maker by market capitalization for the first time, with Nvidia's market cap reaching $251.31 billion compared to Intel's $248.16 billion. This milestone marks Nvidia's shares gaining 74% for the year, while Intel shares have slipped 2%. While other chipmakers like Texas Instruments and Qualcomm have temporarily surpassed Intel in the past, this is a first for Nvidia.

title: Nvidia surpasses Intel as largest U.S. chip maker by market cap
summary: Nvidia Corp. has surpassed Intel Corp. to become the largest U.S. chip maker by market capitalization for the first time. This milestone was achieved on Wednesday, July 8, 2020, with Nvidia's market cap reaching $251.31 billion compared to Intel's $248.16 billion. While other companies like Texas Instruments and Qualcomm have previously and temporarily held the top spot over Intel, this marks a significant achievement for Nvidia.

title: Nvidia Valuation Soars Past Intel on Graphics Chip Boom
summary: Nvidia's market valuation has surpassed Intel's for the first time, driven by high demand for its graphics chips in data centers and other growing tech sectors. Nvidia (NVDA) gained 2.4% on Wednesday, reaching a market value exceeding $248 billion, with its shares up 72% this year, while Intel (INTC) shares have fallen 2%. This surge reflects investor confidence that the pandemic is accelerating a shift to cloud-based digital services utilizing Nvidia's technology.

title: Nvidia on Cusp of Topping Intel in Market Cap After 70% Gain
summary: Nvidia (NVDA) is nearing Intel (INTC) in market capitalization for the first time, buoyed by a more than 70% stock gain in 2020. This surge is attributed to investor confidence that the COVID-19 pandemic is accelerating the shift towards cloud-based digital services, for which Nvidia's technology is crucial. The graphics chipmaker's rapid growth positions it to potentially overtake the long-standing chip giant.

title: Mercedes-Benz and NVIDIA to Build Software-Defined Computing Architecture for Automated Driving Across Future Fleet
summary: Mercedes-Benz and NVIDIA are collaborating to create a revolutionary in-vehicle computing system and AI computing infrastructure for automated driving functions. This software-defined architecture, built on the NVIDIA DRIVE platform, will be rolled out across the next-generation Mercedes-Benz fleet starting in 2024, enabling upgradable automated driving, safety, and convenience features through over-the-air updates. The partnership aims to continually enhance the car ownership experience with a team of AI and software engineers.

title: Mercedes-Benz, Nvidia deepen autonomous driving alliance
authors: Jane Lanhee Lee and Edward Taylor
summary: Semiconductor maker Nvidia Corp has partnered with Daimler to develop a next-generation chip and software platform for Mercedes-Benz cars, enabling advanced autonomous driving functions by 2024. This alliance allows Mercedes to accelerate its development of automated driving capabilities and software applications, with both companies committing significant resources to bringing this technology to market. The platform will enable continuous software updates for Mercedes-Benz vehicles, similar to smartphone updates.

title: Mercedes-Benz cars to be built on Nvidia autonomous driving platform from 2024
summary: Nvidia announced a deal with Daimler Mercedes-Benz to supply a chip and software platform for autonomous driving functions in cars produced from 2024. This partnership will see Nvidia's high-end Drive AGX Orin Platform become standard in Mercedes-Benz vehicles, allowing for over-the-air software updates similar to smartphones. The agreement follows Daimler's decision to pause its autonomous driving alliance with BMW.

title: Intel stock slips as new lines of AI chips released
summary: Intel stock experienced a decline after the company launched new artificial intelligence and data analytics chips. The company's shares fell by 1.2%, underperforming the broader market. This occurred despite new product introductions aimed at supporting AI and data analytics.

title: AMD CEO Lisa Su Tops Earnings as Highest Paid CEO in The S&P 500
summary: AMD CEO Lisa Su has become the highest-paid CEO in the S&P 500, with a pay package valued at $58.5 million. This compensation is attributed to AMD's impressive performance over the past five years, driven by the success of EPYC, Ryzen, and Radeon products. Lisa Su is also the first woman to hold this distinction, being one of only 20 women on the list compared to 309 men.

title: AMD Stock Pushes Lisa Su to Top of CEO Compensation List
summary: Lisa Su, CEO of Advanced Micro Devices (AMD), topped the annual CEO compensation survey by the Associated Press in 2019 with a $58.5 million pay package, largely due to AMD's strong stock performance. She is the first woman to achieve this No. 1 ranking. Her leadership is credited with turning around AMD, focusing the company on high-growth areas like high-performance computing, computer graphics, and graphics processing units.

title: Opinion: It’s official: Nvidia is not just a gaming company anymore
summary: Nvidia's first-quarter earnings report indicates a significant shift from being primarily a gaming company to a major player in the data-center market. Data-center chip sales surpassed $1 billion for the first time, demonstrating its growing importance. This transformation is further highlighted by Nvidia's new business segment reporting, emphasizing both computing and graphics divisions.

title: Nvidia should dodge massive coronavirus effects thanks to data centers and videogames
summary: Nvidia is expected to largely avoid significant negative impacts from the coronavirus pandemic due to strong demand in its data center and videogame segments. The article anticipates data-center sales exceeding $1 billion for the first time and gaming chip growth of 25%. This analysis is part of a series tracking COVID-19's effects on major businesses.

title: What Is a DPU?
summary: This article explains what a Data Processing Unit (DPU) is and how it differs from CPUs and GPUs, positioning it as the third pillar of computing. It details the key components of a DPU, including a multi-core CPU, high-performance network interface, and acceleration engines, emphasizing its role in modern data centers and SmartNICs. The article also outlines ten critical capabilities for network data path acceleration engines within a DPU.

title: TSMC Announces Intention to Build and Operate an Advanced Semiconductor Fab in the United States
summary: TSMC announced its plan to build and operate an advanced semiconductor fab in the U.S. state of Arizona. This facility will use 5nm technology, have a capacity of 20,000 wafers per month, create over 1,600 high-tech jobs directly, and involves a total investment of approximately US$12 billion from 2021 to 2029. The project is strategically important for the U.S. semiconductor ecosystem and relies on continued U.S. federal government and Arizona state support.

title: TSMC’s Announcement Of A New U.S. Semiconductor Fab Is Big News
summary: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) announced plans to build a new semiconductor fabrication facility (fab) in Arizona, a move deemed significant despite its initial limited scale. This investment, estimated at $12 billion for a 5 nm technology fab, highlights the challenges and costs of advanced semiconductor manufacturing. While a welcome development for the U.S. supply chain, it represents only a small step towards securing domestic semiconductor production, as the U.S. will still rely heavily on Asian facilities for capacity and specialized processes like packaging.

title: Taiwanese Chipmaker Plans to Build $12 Billion Factory in Arizona
summary: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) plans to invest $12 billion in building a new chip plant in Arizona, with construction expected to begin in 2021 and completion by 2024. This move is intended to address U.S. national security concerns and shift high-tech manufacturing to the U.S., while also balancing TSMC's relationships with both American clients and China. The facility will create 1,600 jobs and utilize 5-nanometer process technology, though the scale is relatively small compared to TSMC's overall operations.

title: Kensho Collaborates with NVIDIA to Advance Automatic Speech Recognition
summary: Kensho, an S&P Global company, announced Scribe, a new end-to-end speech recognition solution optimized for finance and business. Leveraging NVIDIA NeMo on NVIDIA GPUs, Scribe improves accuracy and expands coverage for earnings calls and other financial audio. Kensho and NVIDIA are continuing to explore further collaboration opportunities to advance automatic speech recognition.

title: Nvidia confirms Ampere will power next-gen GeForce graphics cards
summary: Nvidia has confirmed that its new Ampere GPU architecture will power next-gen GeForce graphics cards, unifying its entire GPU range from gaming to data centers. CEO Jen-Hsun Huang announced that Ampere will replace both Turing and Volta chips, with the architecture also being used in supercomputers to aid in COVID-19 research. While a specific release date for gaming cards wasn't given, an August/September announcement is anticipated.

title: Nvidia Unveils New Data Center Chips to Speed Pace of AI
summary: Nvidia Corp. announced new Ampere graphics chips and computers for AI processing in data centers, claiming a 20x performance increase over predecessors. These new chips are designed to handle both AI training and inference tasks, a capability that will bolster Nvidia's leadership in the growing AI market. The company is selling Ampere-based computers called DGX for $199,000 each, touting their superior performance compared to traditional Intel-based server arrays.

title: COVID-19 Impact and Recovery Analysis | Graphics Processing Unit (GPU) Market 2020-2024 | Demand for High Memory GPU to Boost Growth | Technavio
summary: Technavio projects the Graphics Processing Unit (GPU) market to grow by USD 38.28 billion between 2020 and 2024, with a CAGR exceeding 29%. This growth is primarily driven by the increasing demand for high-memory GPUs, coupled with the expansion of the PC gaming and gaming console markets. The report provides an in-depth analysis of market trends, vendor landscapes, and the impact of COVID-19, segmenting the market by device type and geography.

title: Nvidia shares heading for first record close since coronavirus pandemic
summary: Nvidia shares are on track for a record close, recovering from a COVID-19 related drop, after an analyst boosted the price target ahead of earnings. The analyst cited Nvidia's acquisition of Mellanox Technologies and increased demand for gaming chips and data-center spending as reasons for the upgrade. The company's stock has risen significantly year-to-date, outperforming semiconductor and S&P 500 indexes.

title: Micro but mighty: Semiconductors remain the key to technology leadership
summary: The article emphasizes the critical role of semiconductors in the 21st-century information economy, likening data to "oil" but stressing that semiconductors translate data into usable information. It highlights the United States' historical dominance in this field and its efforts to defend against challenges from countries like Japan in the 1980s and more recently China. The author argues that the U.S. needs a broader strategy beyond export restrictions, involving close collaboration with allies, especially Japan, to maintain its technological leadership.

title: Nvidia to acquire Sequoia-backed networking startup Cumulus Networks
summary: Nvidia Corp. announced its agreement to acquire Cumulus Networks Inc., a data center networking startup backed by $129 million in funding. This acquisition follows Nvidia's $6.9 billion acquisition of Mellanox Technologies Ltd., as Cumulus software is a key component for some Mellanox products. The deal aims to give Nvidia control over a critical software component and align Cumulus' feature development roadmap with its own goals, optimizing the integration of software and hardware.

title: NVIDIA buys Israeli company Mellanox for $7 billion
summary: This article states that NVIDIA bought the Israeli company Mellanox for $7 billion. It appears to be an outdated article reused as part of an announcement about ISRAEL21c becoming part of Unpacked, an OpenDor Media brand. The current content focuses on this transition and what it means for ISRAEL21c's content and community.

title: AMD (NASDAQ:AMD) Reports 41% Year-Over-Year Revenue Growth, Record Notebook Sales
summary: AMD reported Q1 FY2020 earnings with $1.79 billion in revenue, marking a 41% year-over-year growth, despite missing Wall Street analyst expectations and its own previous guidance. The company saw strong performance in Ryzen and EPYC processors and record notebook sales, although overall sequential revenue dropped. AMD remains optimistic about Q2 FY2020, forecasting 21% year-over-year revenue growth.

title: NVIDIA Completes Acquisition of Mellanox, Creating Major Force Driving Next-Gen Data Centers
summary: NVIDIA announced the completion of its $7 billion acquisition of Mellanox Technologies, uniting two leaders in high-performance and data center computing. This strategic move combines NVIDIA's computing expertise with Mellanox's networking technology to enhance performance, resource utilization, and reduce operating costs for customers. The acquisition is expected to immediately benefit NVIDIA's non-GAAP gross margin, non-GAAP EPS, and free cash flow.

title: Nvidia plans to continue to invest in Israel with Mellanox as base, CEO says
summary: Nvidia's CEO Jensen Huang announced the company's intention to continue investing in Israel, leveraging its $7 billion acquisition of Mellanox Technologies Ltd. Mellanox will serve as Nvidia's base in the country, maintaining its operations as a separate entity. The firm highlighted Israel's significant talent pool and its strategic importance as one of Nvidia's largest tech centers globally, with no layoffs planned despite the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Nvidia completes acquisition of Israel’s Mellanox for $7 billion
summary: Nvidia has completed its $7 billion acquisition of Israel-based Mellanox Technologies, uniting two leaders in high-performance and data center computing. This acquisition aims to enhance Nvidia's offerings from AI computing to networking, allowing for higher performance and lower operating costs in next-generation data centers. The deal, initially valued at $6.9 billion, received final approval from Chinese antitrust authorities, paving the way for its completion.

title: Top 10 Processors for AI Acceleration at the Endpoint
summary: This article reviews various processors designed for AI acceleration at the endpoint, highlighting offerings from major companies and startups. It covers application processors like Intel Movidius Myriad X, NXP i.MX 8M Plus, and XMOS xcore.ai, as well as automotive SoCs like Texas Instruments TDA4VM and GPUs such as Nvidia Jetson Nano, detailing their specifications and target applications. The piece provides a snapshot of the current market for AI and machine learning accelerators.

title: GTC Thursdays: Building Out an AI Center of Excellence
summary: This article discusses the importance of establishing an AI Center of Excellence (CoE) to overcome challenges in enterprise AI adoption and accelerate project success. It outlines key considerations for building a CoE, including executive sponsorship, strategic goal setting, data cataloging, infrastructure design, data science strategy, and operational planning with milestones and metrics. The author emphasizes the benefits of centralizing talent and democratizing AI technology access to drive efficiency and higher quality AI outcomes.

title: New Solutions from NetApp Power Enterprise AI Needs
summary: NetApp introduced new AI solutions at the NVIDIA GPU Technology Conference (GTC) Digital event, including a unique AI control plane designed to simplify data-pipeline and provisioning tasks for data scientists and engineers. These solutions, developed in partnership with NVIDIA, aim to accelerate AI adoption and improve the management of AI projects from pilot to production across various industries. NetApp also highlighted enterprise-scale solutions like ONTAP AI and DGX SuperPOD, as well as a new medical imaging solution for healthcare.

title: Apple’s App Store Rules Limit Rival Gaming Services While Arcade Runs Free
summary: Apple's App Store rules are preventing rival gaming services like Google Stadia, Nvidia GeForce, and Microsoft XCloud from reaching iPhone and iPad users. The guidelines ban services that rely on streaming from the cloud, a restriction Apple's own Arcade service bypasses by being integrated as a feature within the App Store. Critics view these rules as arbitrary, favoring Apple's own offerings over those from outside developers.

title: BOTZ: The Robotics/Artificial Intelligence ETF Is Not A Bargain Buy Even After Recent Crash (NASDAQ:BOTZ)
summary: The Global X Robotics & A.I. ETF (BOTZ) has underperformed broader markets, tumbling over 20% year-to-date due to the coronavirus pandemic. Despite the significant drop, the article argues that BOTZ is not a bargain buy, citing subpar earnings growth and profitability among its top holdings. The ETF's heavy exposure to Japan and negative earnings trends in 2019 suggest continued underperformance compared to the broader technology sector and S&P 500.

title: Nvidia tweeted then deleted a video of a blinking eye, what does it mean?
summary: Nvidia tweeted then deleted a mysterious video featuring a blinking eye, leading to speculation about an upcoming announcement on March 19, 2020. The video, which showed an eyeball tracking two points of light, is thought to be related to either Nvidia's next-generation Ampere GPU or foveated rendering technology for virtual reality. This tease comes ahead of Nvidia's annual GPU Technology Conference, which will be an all-digital event.

title: Rambus' HBM2E Memory Controller & PHY Offer Chipmakers Cost-Effective Designs
summary: Rambus has unveiled its HBM2E memory controller and PHY designs, offering chipmakers a cost-effective alternative to in-house R&D. These designs align with the JEDEC HBM2E standard, supporting up to 12-layer 3D stacked DRAM with capacities up to 36GB and an aggregate memory bandwidth of 410 GBps. HBM2E is expected to primarily impact AI and high-performance computing applications where high bandwidth and limited board space are crucial.

title: Nvidia secures SwiftStack technology -by buying the company
summary: Nvidia has acquired SwiftStack, an object storage software company, to enhance its internal data centers and provide its AI Stack solutions to customers. Nvidia will integrate SwiftStack's 1space technology to ensure GPUs are constantly fed with data, but does not intend to become a storage vendor. The acquisition highlights a trend of object storage companies becoming instrumental for end-to-end vertical solutions.

title: Nvidia acquires data storage and management platform SwiftStack
summary: Nvidia has acquired SwiftStack, a software-centric data storage and management platform, to enhance its AI, high-performance computing, and accelerated computing workloads. SwiftStack's co-founder Joe Arnold expressed excitement about joining Nvidia to contribute to its AI supercomputing efforts. While the acquisition price was not disclosed, SwiftStack had previously raised $23.6 million in funding.

title: Nvidia Moves Conference To Online-Only Amid COVID-19 Concerns
summary: Nvidia Corp has canceled the in-person component of its annual user conference scheduled for March 22-26 due to COVID-19 concerns, opting instead for an online-only format. CEO Jensen Huang will still deliver a keynote address via livestream, and attendees who paid for passes will receive full refunds. The move comes as analysts anticipated Nvidia to announce new products with advanced chipmaking processes.

title: Humanoid Robot Market Demand, Current Outlook, Future Growth,
summary: The humanoid robot market is experiencing significant growth driven by increasing adoption in retail, education, research, and caregiving, as well as technological advancements. Software is expected to dominate the market due to the integration of AI algorithms, while biped motion types also hold a significant share. North America currently leads the market, but the Asia-Pacific region is projected to show the fastest growth.

title: AI Helps Doctors Diagnose the Coronavirus | NVIDIA Technical Blog
summary: Physicians in Wuhan, China, are utilizing AI software accelerated by NVIDIA GPUs to detect visual signs of Covid-19, aiding in patient screening and prioritizing those likely to have the virus. The AI software, developed by Infervision, was fine-tuned with over 2,000 CT images from early coronavirus patients and trained on NVIDIA V100 GPUs. This solution has been deployed in 34 hospitals across China, reviewing over 32,000 cases, and is being evaluated in Europe and the United States.

title: Nvidia stock rockets past $300 to third straight record close as holdout analyst turns bullish
summary: Nvidia stock surpassed $300 for the first time, reaching a third consecutive record close due to an analyst's increased bullishness. Bernstein analyst Stacy Rasgon upgraded Nvidia's rating from market perform to outperform and raised his price target to $360 from $300. This shift marks a significant positive turn for the stock as a previously holdout analyst acknowledges an "error" in not being more positive sooner.

title: Samsung wins 5-nanometer modem chip contract from Qualcomm
summary: Samsung Electronics has secured a contract to manufacture Qualcomm's new 5G X60 modem chips using its advanced 5-nanometer process technology, marking a significant win for Samsung in its competition with TSMC. This deal is crucial for Samsung's efforts to expand its non-memory chip business and regain market share in the foundry sector. The X60 modem chips are expected to be widely used in 5G mobile devices, potentially boosting Samsung's market presence.

title: Nvidia stock closes at record as data-center sales inspire analyst love fest
summary: Nvidia's stock soared to a new record high on Friday, driven by robust data-center sales that exceeded expectations after a challenging year. Analysts responded positively by raising price targets, as the company's shares closed up 7% at $289.79, marking its first record close in nearly a year and a half. This surge highlights investor confidence in Nvidia's performance in the data-center market.

title: Nvidia forecast tops expectations on cloud sales despite coronavirus hit
summary: Nvidia Corp exceeded Wall Street's first-quarter revenue expectations, driven by strong sales of its chips to cloud computing vendors, despite projecting a $100 million hit due to the coronavirus outbreak. This forecast signals a rebound in chip demand, particularly in the data center business, which helped offset a slight miss in gaming revenue and increased Nvidia's shares. The company expects current-quarter revenue of $3 billion, plus or minus 2%.

title: An A+ ETF For AV and AI Tech
summary: This article highlights the ARK Autonomous Technology & Robotics ETF (ARKQ) as a prime investment vehicle for artificial intelligence (AI) and autonomous vehicles (AV) technologies. ARKQ is noted for its significant allocation to Tesla and its strategic positioning to benefit from the growth in these disruptive technologies. The article delves into how AI, particularly machine learning and deep learning, is crucial for AV development due to the massive data processing requirements from vehicle sensors.

title: How analog in-memory computing can solve power challenges of edge AI inference
summary: This article explores how analog in-memory computing can address the significant power consumption and latency issues of edge AI inference, which are prevalent with cloud-based AI solutions. It highlights the memory bottleneck in traditional digital computing and introduces a multi-level memory architecture, like Microchip Technology's memBrain, that integrates computation directly into memory, dramatically reducing power usage. The technology utilizes SuperFlash memory cells to perform Multiply-Accumulate operations efficiently at the edge, offering extreme low power, smaller footprint, and lower development costs for AI applications.

title: MRCY Stock Price | Analyst Target 75.14 & Moderate Buy Consensus
summary: This article provides an overview of Mercury Systems Inc (MRCY) stock, detailing its current price, analyst consensus of "Moderate Buy" with a target of $75.14, and company information. It covers key metrics, recent news, and instructs on how to buy MRCY stock on eToro. The company is a technology firm serving the aerospace and defense industry with mission-critical products.

title: Intel dumps its Nervana neural network processors for Habana’s AI chips
summary: Intel Corp. has decided to discontinue development of its Nervana neural network processors, opting instead to focus on the AI chip technology acquired with Habana Labs Ltd. for $2 billion. This decision comes as Habana's chips, such as the Gaudi and Goya, have demonstrated superior performance compared to Nervana's NNP-T and NNP-I processors. The move could have implications for Intel's AI Platforms Group, led by a Nervana co-founder, raising questions about potential mergers with Habana.

title: One Stop Systems follows up record revenue in 2019 with addition to “AI on the Fly” line
summary: One Stop Systems (OSS) reported record revenue of $58.3 million in 2019, a 57 percent gain over the previous year, driven by corporate acquisitions and new design wins in enterprise and military markets. The company is expanding its "AI on the Fly" product line with a new PCIe 4.0 value expansion system that incorporates the NVIDIA V100S Tensor Core GPU. This addition aims to meet the growing demand for high-performance edge computing systems capable of processing AI algorithms closer to data sources, particularly in mission-critical applications.

title: Corsair One i164 SFF PC Review
summary: This review examines the Corsair One i164, a small form factor (SFF) PC featuring an Intel 9900K and NVIDIA GeForce RTX 2080 Ti. The article details its design, I/O, cooling system, and internal specifications, highlighting its quiet operation and powerful components. It assesses whether this new iteration lives up to the high recommendations of its predecessor.

title: CES 2020 | Panasonic unveils world's first UHD HDR VR glasses
summary: Panasonic unveiled the world's first UHD HDR VR glasses at CES 2020, significantly boosting resolution and adding HDR compatibility in a lightweight design. This was achieved through a collaboration with Kopin for advanced micro-OLED displays and by integrating Panasonic's proprietary audio/video technologies. While not yet available commercially due to high production costs, Panasonic plans further development for a future release, potentially coinciding with the wider adoption of 5G services.

title: NVIDIA Announces New G-SYNC Esports Displays
summary: NVIDIA has announced new G-SYNC displays featuring a 360Hz refresh rate, designed for competitive gamers and esports enthusiasts. These displays, including the ASUS ROG Swift 360, are up to 6X faster than traditional gaming displays, providing tear-free visuals and incredibly low latency. The announcement highlights the rapid expansion of esports and NVIDIA's continued innovation in gaming display technology.

title: Investors Love Thematic ETFs and Mutual Funds, but They Aren’t Always Loved Back - WSJ
authors: Tyler Comrie By Michael A. Pollock
summary: Thematic ETFs and mutual funds are popular among investors, allowing them to invest in specific trends like AI, clean energy, or space. However, these funds can often disappoint despite investor enthusiasm. The article suggests strategies for investors to better manage their thematic fund investments.

title: Investors Love Thematic ETFs and Mutual Funds, but They Aren’t Always Loved Back - WSJ
summary: This article discusses the popularity of thematic ETFs and mutual funds among investors, despite their potential for disappointment. It highlights how these funds allow investors to target specific industries like space, AI, or clean energy. The article also mentions the performance of several thematic funds through October, suggesting that investors should approach them with caution.

title: Highflying Nvidia’s Deal for Arm Signals Loftier Chip Ambition
summary: Nvidia's $40 billion acquisition of Arm Holdings from SoftBank Group Corp. is poised to significantly impact the global semiconductor industry. The deal involves a mix of cash and stock, with potential additional payments based on Arm's financial performance. This transaction further elevates Nvidia's position and represents another major move for SoftBank.

title: Glow-in-the-Dark Monkeys and a Man Who Cooks Diamonds: 2019's Best Interviews
summary: This article looks back at some of the most astonishing and inspiring interviews of 2019 reported by CTech.
